question: What kind of specialist is Steffie going to see?
dialogue:
Helga: Hello, how are you doing today?
Steffie: I ' Ve been having trouble breathing lately.
Helga: Have you had any type of cold lately?
Steffie: No, I haven ' t had a cold. I just have a heavy feeling in my chest when I try to breathe.
Helga: Do you have any allergies that you know of?
Steffie: No, I don ' t have any allergies that I know of.
Helga: Does this happen all the time or mostly when you are active?
Steffie: It happens a lot when I work out.
Helga: I am going to send you to a pulmonary specialist who can run tests on you for asthma.
Steffie: Thank you for your help, doctor.
summary: a pulmonary specialist

Ned: Wow. Sounds fantastic!
summary: Ned finds Merrili's dreams fantastic.

question: How does Lorrie feel about quitting smoking?
dialogue:

question: Why does Hilary want to go to the beach?
dialogue:
Hilary: Hey, Karen. Look like you got some sun this weekend.

Karen: Some friends of my parents live out there, and they invited me there.
Hilary: So, what did you do out there? I mean besides bask in the sun, obviously.

Karen: I wanted to, but the water is too cold, and I just wetted in up to my knees.
Hilary: It all sounds so relaxing. I wish I could get away to the beach like that.
Karen: It looks like you could use it. Don't tell me you spent the weekend in the library again.
summary: it's relaxing

instruction: Please answer the following question from DialogSum dataset.
question: What do Lita and Garvey both hate?
dialogue:
Lita: There are advertisements everywhere here in hong kong. The city is so bright at night, with all the neon signs.
Garvey: I like it. It makes the city feel alive. I like all the different colors and I like the billboards with eye-catching pictures and slogans.
Lita: I think that there are too many of them. I think that companies spend far too much money on advertising. They should have lower prices instead. Then they would see more.
Garvey: I see your point, but if companies didn't spend money on advertising, no one would hear about their products. I agree that some form of advertising can be annoying. I don't like it when people try to give you leaflets with information about products you have no intention of buying.
Lita: I really hate receiving spam. I also dislike having to listen to advertisements and jingles when they are broadcast in stores or on the subway.
Garvey: Yes, that annoys me too. With billboards, you can look away, but with broadcasts, you can't avoid them. I like the way that advertising agencies use comedy in their campaign.
Lita: I like that too. I don't like the way that advertising campaign often tell you if you don't buy a certain product, you're not cool or modern or efficient or something.
Garvey: That kind of advertising seems to be very common with brand name products. They are always trying to maintain brand loyalty.
summary: leaflets and broadcasts

question: What does JoAnn suggest Mr. Zhang do?
dialogue:
JoAnn: Hi, Mr. Zhang. What's wrong? You don't look so happy. How was your date?
Mr. Zhang: I was turned down again. It's frustrating. I guess you'Ve got to teach me some skills.
JoAnn: Me? I'm even less experienced than you are.
Mr. Zhang: At least you know what American women generally like in a man.
JoAnn: Believe it or not, I guess American women like a man in good shape, which Chinese women may not care about so much. That's my honest opinion. I know you have been trying very hard.
Mr. Zhang: American men are naturally taller than Chinese men. So even if I exercise, there aren't many chances.
JoAnn: No, that's not true. I'Ve met two American women who were married to Chinese. But those Chinese look very strong and healthy. So if you exercise more often, I bet it will surely be easier for you to date American girls. How old is Jacky Chan? He's small and short. But I bet he can have any American woman he wants.
Mr. Zhang: You know, that's going to be a tremendous change for me. Because I never exercise.
JoAnn: Why don't you try then? Even if it doesn't help you find an American girl, you could still have a stronger and healthier body. You won't lose anything by doing that.
summary: try to exercise to be in good shape so he can find a date with American women.

instruction: Please answer the following question from DialogSum dataset.
question: What does Deena want to know?
dialogue:
Deena: Is there a city where it's always warm?
Ray: Yes, there are many cities where it's almost always warm. San Diego, for example.
Deena: Are there any other cities where it's always hot?
Ray: Many. Most of the cities in the southern part of the United States are hot all year.
Deena: But why do so many people live there?
Ray: Most people grow accustomed to the climate, but there are many others who complain about it all the time.
Deena: Are there any cities where it rains a lot?
Ray: Several. Two good examples are Seattle, in the state of Washington, and Portland, Oregon.
Deena: Tell us about some cold cities.
Ray: In the north there are many cities which are very cold in the winter. Boston and Chicago are two of them.
Deena: Is it always cold in Chicago and Boston?
Ray: Oh, no. On the contrary, there are many beautiful days, especially in the spring and fall.
summary: the cities where it's always warm, hot, rains a lot, and cold respectively

Sara: Yes, I know. The problem is that I can't find it. Where did you put it?
Higgins: All your important documents and certificates should be in the desk drawer.
Sara: Oh, yes, here it is.
Higgins: Sara?
Sara: What's up?
Higgins: Did you buy a map? Traveling can be really inconvenient without one, and you could even wind up lost
Sara: No. Dad. We have a tour guide.
Higgins: Also, take these pills in case you have any airsickness, and take some cold medicine, too. How about some band-aids?
Sara: No, I won't get sick. I promise. Ok. I've finished. Bye, Dad. See you!

Sara: Dad, that's all right. I don't think it will rain. And it doesn't make any sense to take that many things on a trip. Besides I like to travel light. Bye!
summary: Sara decides not to take several items to pack for the trip except her ID card because she likes to travel light.

dialogue:
Loreen: Good afternoon, Miss Qi.
Miss Qi: Good afternoon. It's very nice to see you again.
Loreen: How are you feeling today?
Miss Qi: I'm much better. The stomachache is gone, and the doctor is about to give me another endoscope examination to see whether the ulcer has healed.
Loreen: That's good. Well, these are for you. I hope you will like them.
Miss Qi: How beautiful they are! Thank you so much.
Loreen: I've also brought some magazines for you. I hope they'll keep you from getting bored while you're in the hospital.
Miss Qi: You're so thoughtful!
Loreen: It's time for me to leave. I hope you will recover soon. See you later.
Miss Qi: Thank you for coming. Good - bye.
summary: Loreen visits Miss Qi in the hospital and brings some magazines to keep her from getting bored.

instruction: Please answer the following question from DialogSum dataset.
question: What will Irene do for Amy?
dialogue:
Irene: Amy, you don't look so well. What happened?
Amy: Yes. I feel terrible. I have been coughing for the whole morning.
Irene: Do you feel anything else?
Amy: Yes. I feel chilly and sluggish.
Irene: Have you had similar feelings before?
Amy: No. This is my first day abroad. I am not sure what is wrong with me.
Irene: Don't worry. I believe you are just not agreeing with the local climate. I will get you some medicine. You will be alright after a good rest.
Amy: Thank you very much.
summary: Irene will get her some medicine.

instruction: Please answer the following question from DialogSum dataset.
question: What does Karly list as a health food?
dialogue:
Julianne: Do you know anything about health food?
Karly: It is so popular among people to preserve health now, so I read some books about health food.
Julianne: Can you give me some examples?
Karly: Drinking warm and fresh water in the morning on wakening up is one of ways to keep healthy.
Julianne: Really? Why we must have warm and fresh water?
Karly: Warm water can be good for your stomach, which is empty at that moment. And freshness can keep the water active to clean your digest system.
Julianne: Anything else?
Karly: Yogurt, because it has protein, vitamins and it is acidic. If you drink it everyday, your stomach will be more comfortable.
summary: warm and fresh water and yogurt

instruction: Please answer the following question from DialogSum dataset.
question: What does John Keat need to bring to the doctor's office?
dialogue:
Jo: Good afternoon, Dr. Anderson's office.
John Keat: Hello, my name is John Keat, and I was hoping I could come in today to see the doctor.
Jo: Are you a patient of Dr. Anderson?
John Keat: Well, no. I'm at a convention from Mexico and the manager of the hotel where I'm staying suggested that I call you.
Jo: Well, I see. What seems to be the problem?
John Keat: Well, I got this ringing in my ears. It's so terrible that I can hardly hear people talking now.
Jo: Are you in any pain or is there any fluid?
John Keat: No discharge, just a slight earache.
Jo: Does the pain happen all the time, or once in a while.
John Keat: It has been aching for two days and it's never stopped. I thought it might be due to my flying in the air, and after some rest it'll be all gone. But who knows it's getting worse. I need to see the doctor.
Jo: The doctor will be busy at the hospital until this evening. The earliest you could see him would be tomorrow morning at ten.
John Keat: The time is good for me. I'll come in then if that's okay.
Jo: That will be fine; in the meantime you should try to take it easy. Don't press your ear and don't have water in when you take a shower.
John Keat: Do I have to bring something when I'm seeing the doctor, since I have never seen a doctor in Canada.
Jo: For foreign visitors, I guess you may bring your passport for the hospital registration.
John Keat: Yes, I will. Thank you for your help.
Jo: Thanks for calling. See you.
summary: John Keat needs to bring his passport to the doctor's office.

instruction: Please answer the following question from DialogSum dataset.
question: What does John Cruise complain about?
dialogue:
Eve Wheeler: Sound and Vision, Administrative Department, Eve Wheeler speaking. Can I help you?
John Cruise: Good afternoon, madam. This is John Cruise. I wish to register a complaint about my video recorder.
Eve Wheeler: I see. I hope I can be of some help. Can you explain what the problem is, please?
John Cruise: Well, the recorder has severely damaged two quite valuable tapes of mine. And you guaranteed that this machine is the best there. I hope you understand that a simple repair is just not enough. I demand compensation for the lost tapes as well.
Eve Wheeler: I'm sorry. That's all very unfortunate. I'm sure something can be done. I will put you through to our legal consulant, Mrs. Schroder. One moment, please. (dialing sound...) Hello, Mr. Cruise? Thank you for waiting. I'm awfully sorry, but Mrs. Schroder is having a meeting right now. Could she call you back later this afternoon?
John Cruise: I hope you're not trying to get rid of me.
Eve Wheeler: Not at all, sir. I have noted your complaint and I will urge Mrs. Schroder to call you back as soon as possible. Could I have your phone number, please?
John Cruise: Yes. It's 0181 945 8719.
Eve Wheeler: Thank you very much. Goodbye.
summary: his video recorder

instruction: Please answer the following question from DialogSum dataset.
question: Why does Miss Winters ask Hong to do a special project?
dialogue:
Miss Winters: Hong, it seems like you really struggle to learn English, is this level too hard for you?
Hong: I don't know. I think it's just boring. I don't like the workbooks because the lessons talk about baby things. I'm not a little child. I want to learn something more exciting.
Miss Winters: Hmm, I have an idea that you'll like. This week, you can do a special project for class.
Hong: Oh, what's that?
Miss Winters: I want you to watch some YouTube videos of people speaking in different English accents. I'll send you the links for the ones you should watch, they're very funny. One person does about 30 different accents in 10 minutes.
Hong: Wow, that's great, but, won't it be harder for me to learn English if I'm listening to so many different ways of speaking the language?
Miss Winters: It shouldn't, this is just a fun project to help you get more interested in the lessons. There is a more serious side to it, though. I want you to write a one page essay about the videos and tell the class about your project on Friday. You can show some of the videos during your presentation too if you like. I think the whole class will benefit from this.
Hong: I can't wait to get started. Thank you, Miss Winters.
summary: Hong thinks learning English is boring and wants something more exciting

Julianna: Well, direct ones are the pollution directly from factories, refineries waste treatment plants etc. , aren't they?

Julianna: I see. For the sake of us all, we should be an active participator in the prevention of it.
Elysha: Sure. It's an issue asking for everyone's participation.

question: What does Wang need to do after the car accident?
dialogue:
Sasha: Why don't you watch where you're going?

Wang: Hey, listen. I had every right to stay in the lane I was in. You were supposed to wait until I passed to pull out. And anyhow, you didn't give me any time to change lanes. All of a sudden--BANG--there you are right in front of me.
Sasha: I think my arm is broken.
Wang: Sorry about your arm, but it serves you right. You need to learn how to drive. You're lucky you didn't get killed. And I'm lucky to be alive too.
Sasha: Listen, let's just wait until the police get here. Then we can decide whose fault this accident was.
Wang: Fine with me. I know the laws of the road. I'm not worried.
Sasha: I have a cell phone in my car. Now it's probably on the floor on the passenger side. Why don't you get it for me, and then I can call the police?
Wang: Alright.
Sasha: It doesn't work. It looks like it's broken. I need to get to a hospital. You should drive me there.
Wang: Oh, yeah? It's better if we make a police report first. Then you can go to the hospital.
Sasha: Damn it! I'm injured here. We could wait all day for the police.
Wang: Well, you'll just have to wait. I'm not going to move my car until the police arrive. I'll go into one of those houses over there and use their phone. Don't worry. You'll get to the hospital in time.
Sasha: It really hurts.
Wang: Yes, maybe it does. But if you're going to drive like you did just now, you will have to get used to a little physical pain. You know what I mean?
Sasha: To hell with you. The accident was your fault.
Wang: I'm afraid it wasn't. And when the police get here, you will also see that it wasn't. But enough of this bickering. I'm going to go find a phone. Don't move that arm while I'm gone. Alright?
Sasha: To hell with you.
summary: Wang needs to find a phone to call the police to decide whose fault this accident was.

instruction: Please answer the following question from DialogSum dataset.
question: How long did it take Kevin to get married to Andrea?
dialogue:
Laura: Hi Kevin!
Kevin: Hi Laura, long time no see! What have you been up to lately?

Kevin: Much the same except I do have some big news.
Laura: Come on. This suspense is killing me.
Kevin: No, really, what have you been doing these past few weeks? The last time I saw you, you were looking for a new job.
Laura: Well, that's not exactly true. I was thinking about changing jobs. Luckily, they offered me a new position in the accounting department.
Kevin: A step up in the big business world.
Laura: I wouldn't exaggerate, but I am pleased. I had been hoping to get a promotion for a while. So when it finally came through, I was relieved. Actually, that's why I was looking for a new job. I just didn't want to work there anymore if they weren't going to recognize my efforts.
Kevin: Right, sometimes you can do your best and it seems like the others don't know you exist. I hope the money's better.
Laura: I got a reasonable raise, now enough about me. I'm dying to hear your news.
Kevin: I am getting married.
Laura: No, you said you'd never get married.
Kevin: That was then and this is now. You've got to meet Andrea, she's great!
Laura: This is all news to me. I didn't even know you were dating.
Kevin: We weren't. We've just been dating for two weeks now.
Laura: And you getting married?
Kevin: I know. I can't help it. I just know she's the one.
Laura: Well, congratulations! That's fantastic!
Kevin: Thanks, I'm glad to hear you feel way.
summary: Kevin got married to Andrea after dating for 2 weeks.

instruction: Please answer the following question from DialogSum dataset.
question: Why does Carly need a babysitter?
dialogue:
Carly: Listen, Karen, I need your help. I don't know anyone here yet. 
Karen: I'm glad to help you. What's wrong? 
Carly: My mother-in-law just went into the hospital in L. A. Hank and I will be flying there tonight. 
Karen: I'm sorry to hear it. What's wrong with her? 
Carly: Doctors aren't sure yet. But the real problem is Suzy. She has a bad cold, and we don't want to take her with us. But we don't know who can stay with her. 
Karen: You need a babysitter. 
Carly: Yes, I'd ask Jill, the girl I've had before, but I need someone overnight. Maybe even for two nights. 
Karen: I could have Suzy stay at my place. 
Carly: I don't want to do that to you, Karen. 
Karen: Why not? 
Carly: Your own kids would get Suzy's cold. I think it would be better to have a good babysitter here. But I don't know who to ask. I need someone more mature than Jill. It might even be for two or three days. 
Karen: I know who we can ask. There is a girl I know, Sara Ralston. She is 17, and she will usually take this kind of job. I know her from my church, and I trust her completely. 
Carly: I'd like to talk with her. This is short notice, I know. But Hank and I are leaving tonight. 
Karen: I'll get you her number. I hope she can do it. She is very responsible. 
Carly: I'm glad you know someone. I knew you would be the best person to ask about this. I don't want to insult Jill or her mother. I think Jill maybe could do it. But I'd rather have someone a little older. 
Karen: I'll go home and get Sara's number. I'll call her first myself. 
Carly: Great. Then call me and let me know if she's free.
summary: to see Carly's mother-in-law in the hospital

instruction: Please answer the following question from DialogSum dataset.
question: What country was Kelila in?
dialogue:
Cassie: How was your summer trip?
Kelila: It was great. My friend and I travelled throughout India.
Cassie: Sounds hot! How did you get along without studying the local language?
Kelila: Most People there speak English. But there were some remote places in the mountains where we had to learn a few words to communicate. Usually it was easy. One time, though, it got a little awkward. I was asking a baker for some bread and I said 'I want money' instead of 'I want bread'. The words for money and bread were so similar that I got them mixed up.
Cassie: How did the baker react?
Kelila: He looked a little scared but my friend quickly cleared up the confusion. We ended up becoming friends with the guy and he introduced us to more young people. Whenever we told the story of our meeting, it would make everyone laugh.
summary: Kelila tells Cassie about a funny experience about language confusion during the summer trip in India.

instruction: Please answer the following question from DialogSum dataset.
question: Why does Mr. Brown refuse to advance the time of delivery?
dialogue:
Franklin: Now we have settled the terms of payment. Is it possible to effect shipment during September?
Mr. Brown: I don't think we can.
Franklin: Then when is the earliest we can expect shipment?
Mr. Brown: By the middle of October, I think.
Franklin: That's too late. You see, November is the season for this commodity in our market, and our Customs formalities are rather complicated.
Mr. Brown: I understand.
Franklin: Besides, the flow through the marketing channels and the red tape involved take at least a couple of weeks. Thus, after shipment it will be four to five weeks altogether before the goods can reach our retailers. The goods must therefore be shipped before October ; otherwise we won't be in time for the selling season.
Mr. Brown: But our factories are fully committed for the third quarter. In fact, many of our clients are placing orders for delivery in the fourth quarter.
Franklin: Mr. Brown, you certainly realize that the time of delivery is a matter of great importance to us. If we place our goods on the market at a time when all other importers have already sold their goods at profitable prices, we shall lose out.
Mr. Brown: I see your point. However, we have done more business this year than any of the previous years. I am very sorry to say that we cannot advance the time of delivery.
Franklin: That's too bad, but I sincerely hope you will give our request your special consideration.
Mr. Brown: You may take it from me that the last thing we want to do is to disappoint an old customer like you. But the fact remains that our manufacturers have a heavy backlog on their hands.
Franklin: But can't you find some way to get round your producers for an earlier delivery? Make a special effort, please. A timely delivery means a lot to us.
Mr. Brown: All right. We'll get in touch with our producers and see what they have to say.
summary: several specific reasons, but finally Mr. Brown is persuaded to contact the producers to see if they can help

instruction: Please answer the following question from DialogSum dataset.
question: Who does Bonnie want to speak to?
dialogue:
Bengt: Good afternoon, how can I help you?
Bonnie: Someone has stolen my gold necklace.
Bengt: I am sorry to hear about that. Would you mind coming with me to my office and tell me exactly what happened here?
Bonnie: Of course not.
Bengt: Are you sure that it isn't somewhere in your room?
Bonnie: Yes, I've looked everywhere in my room and I can't find it.
Bengt: Ok, when and where did you last see it?
Bonnie: Last night on the dresser. I took it off before I went to the shower, and forgot to put it back on after the shower. And this morning I left the hotel in a hurry without wearing it.
Bengt: Are you sure you didn't wear it this morning?
Bonnie: Yes, I am positive.
Bengt: Did you remember to lock your door before you left then?
Bonnie: Yes, I think I did. It has to be one of your maids who took it. I want my necklace back.
Bengt: Well, I understand how you feel, and we will try to do our best to help you. But first please allow me to send one of the housemaids to your room to look for it again thoroughly, just in case it's still in there. If she finds it, we will all be happy. If she doesn't, we will turn the whole matter to the police. But I must say that the hotel can't be held responsible for your loss. You should have locked your gold necklace away at the hotel's safety box. If you had read your key card carefully, you would have realized that we specially warned you to do so.
Bonnie: That just isn't good enough. Cet me your general manager. I want to speak to him now.
Bengt: I am sorry, ma'am. Our general manager is not in town. But I'd be more than glad to get you our assistant manager, if you like. But I am afraid that he will say the same thing. We have very clear instructions about valuables and we must follow them. And now if you will excuse me, I'll go and find our assistant manager for you.
summary: Bonnie wants to speak to the general manager.

instruction: Please answer the following question from DialogSum dataset.
question: Who is the action organizer of Green Peace?
dialogue:
Moise: Right, well, in the studio this morning, for our interview spot is Peter Wilson. Peter works for Green Peace. So, Peter, welcome.
Peter Wilson: Thanks a lot. It's good to be here.
Moise: Great! Now, Peter, perhaps you can tell us something about Green Peace and your job there.
Peter Wilson: Sure. Well, I'll start by telling you roughly what Green Peace is all about. I actually work in London for the Green Peace organization. We've been going for a few decades and we're a non-violent, non-political organization. We're involved in anti-nuclear activity, conservation and protection of animals and protection and support of our eco-system. I'm the action organizer and arrange any protests.
Moise: Right! A pretty important role, Peter. What sort of protest would you organize?
Peter Wilson: Well, recently we've been involved in anti-nuclear campaigns. I've personally arranged for the demonstration against radioactive waste dumping in the Atlantic Ocean. We've got a few small Green Peace boats that we harass the dumping ship with.
Moise: Say? Hold on, Peter. I thought you said your organization was non-violent. What do you mean by 'harass'?
Peter Wilson: Well, we circle round and round the ships and get in the way when they try to dump the drums of nuclear waste in the sea. We talk to the men and try to change, you know, yell at them to stop. We generally make ourselves as much of a nuisance as possible. 
Moise: Well, people may think differently of your methods, but there's no doubt you're doing a great job. Keep it up and good luck. And thanks for talking with us.
summary: Peter Wilson who is the action organizer of Green Peace organization. Moise asks Peter to introduce to the audience whatGreen Peace is and what work it does. Peter also introduces detailed anti-nuclear campaigns.

Bill: Yes, I can. In fact, these are better than climbing shoes. The spring design means they're much more powerful.
summary: his legs were removed because of a terrible accident in the mountain

Emily: I try to be sensible about it, but it's not very easy. Sometimes you just have to grin and bear it.

instruction: Please answer the following question from DialogSum dataset.
question: What does Devin want to know about Emmye?
dialogue:
Devin: What made you decide on this type of occupation?
Emmye: Oh, to tell you the truth, I love the sky. When I was a child, I imagined flying into the blue sky some day. Now, I think the day has come. My dream will come true. And I like travelling very much and I enjoy working with people.
Devin: Can you make yourself understood in English without too much difficulty?
Emmye: Yes, I think I am quite fluent in English. I got the certificate of the Secondary English Training last month.
Devin: Do you know what the responsibilities are for a stewardess?
Emmye: The main responsibility of the stewardess is to make the passengers relaxed and happy during the flight. And good service is also important.
Devin: Are you in good health?
Emmye: I just had a complete physical examination and I am in top condition.
Devin: Have you had any nursing experience?
Emmye: Yes, I have two years of nursing experience, and now I am working as a nurse in a hospital.
Devin: How tall are you? What about your eyesight?
Emmye: My height is one meter and sixty-eight centimeters. I've never had any vision problems.
Devin: What would you say are your strengths and weaknesses?
Emmye: One of my strengths is my friendliness and open-minded attitude and also I think I have a warm personality. But sometimes, I find it is hard to tell others when I don't like what they are doing.
Devin: If a passenger can't understand what you say, what should you do?
Emmye: I'll try to speak in another language or I'll try my best to use gestures and draw pictures.
summary: motivation, English level, health condition, nursing experience, height, eyesight, strengths, weaknesses, etc

Srinivas: Slacker and those who violate working principles.
summary: Srinivas

question: What does Teriann want to do with the article?
dialogue:
Otis: You're going to wear out the computer's keyboard!
Teriann: Oh, hi.
Otis: Do you have any idea what time it is?
Teriann: About ten or ten-thirty?
Otis: It's nearly midnight.
Teriann: Really? I didn't know it was so late.
Otis: Don't you have an early class to teach tomorrow morning?
Teriann: Yes, at seven o'clock. My commuter class, the students who go to work right after their lesson.
Otis: Then you ought to go to bed. What are you writing, anyway?
Teriann: An article I hope I can sell.
Otis: Oh, another of your newspaper pieces? What's this one about?
Teriann: Do you remember the trip I took last month?
Otis: The one up to the Amazon?
Teriann: Well, that's what I'm writing about-the new highway and the changes it's making in the Amazon valley.
Otis: It should be interesting.
Teriann: It is. I guess that's why I forgot all about the time.
Otis: How many articles have you sold now?
Teriann: About a dozen so far.
Otis: What kind of newspapers buy them?
Teriann: The papers that carry a lot of foreign news. They usually appear in the big Sunday editions where they need a lot of background stories to help fill up the space between the ads.
Otis: Is there any future in it?
Teriann: I hope so. There's a chance I may sell this article to a news service.
Otis: Then your story would be published in several papers, wouldn't it?
Teriann: That's the idea. And I might even be able to do other stories on a regular basis.
Otis: That would be great.
summary: sell the article to a news service

instruction: Please answer the following question from DialogSum dataset.
question: How much did Aditya sell the tie for?
dialogue:
Aditya: Hi young lady. How may I help you?
Ranee: Well, ... yeah. I'm looking for a Father's Day gift.
Aditya: Okay. How about getting your father a new wallet?
Ranee: Hmm. How much is that wallet?
Aditya: Huh ... which one?
Ranee: The black one.
Aditya: Oh. It's only $40.95.
Ranee: Huh? That's too expensive for me. Do you have a cheaper one?
Aditya: Hmm. How about this brown leather one?
Ranee: Umm... I don't think my father will like the design on the outside, and it doesn't have a place to put pictures. How much is it anyway?
Aditya: It's $25.99.
Ranee: Humm. I don't have that much money.
Aditya: Okay. How much money do you have to spend?
Ranee: I'm not sure [money falling on the table]. Probably about ten dollars or so. I've been helping my mom around the house for the past week to earn some money. This is all I have.
Aditya: Hmm. How about this tie?
Ranee: That's real pretty, but the price tag says $13.99, and I know I don't have that much money.
Aditya: Well, let's just say the tie went on sale. How about $5.00. What do you say?
Ranee: Oh, thanks. I'll take it.
summary: $5, so he sold it for $5 + $13.99 = $18.

summary: Doe's white blood cell count

summary: John wants Miss Ames to oil her door because the door is noisy.

question: What did David do after he fell off his skateboard and landed in a pool?
dialogue:
Heywood: Hi, David. How was your day?
David: Don't ask, it was terrible.
Heywood: You poor thing. What on earth happened?
David: Well, at about 11 o'clock this morning, I was skateboarding in the park.
Heywood: Oh, yes? Did you see Tony there?
David: No. Luckily, I didn't see anyone I know.
Heywood: What do you mean 'luckily'?
David: To start with, I wasn't looking where I was going and I fell off my skateboard. I landed in a pool. I was really dirty.
Heywood: Oh, no. What did you do?
David: Well, I was getting on the bus to come home, when the driver shouted at me. He didn't let me on the bus because I was wet and dirty. And I didn't have any money for a taxi. I walked all the way home.
Heywood: Oh, dear...
summary: had to walk all the way home

question: Why did Tommy's mom ask him to report it to the policeman?
dialogue:
Valma: You look upset. Are you OK, Tommy?
Tommy: I'm fine, mom. It's just your cellphone. You lent it to me this morning.
Valma: Yes, is something wrong with it? No, don't tell me you dropped and broke it.
Tommy: No, I was texting Jack outside a store and somebody ran past and grabbed it.
Valma: You mean someone stole my phone?
Tommy: I am afraid so. Everything just happened so suddenly. I was too shocked.
Valma: So you didn't see who it was?
Tommy: No. It was someone in a white shirt. But there's a camera on the entrance. It might have got a shot of the thief's face.
Valma: You've reported it then?
Tommy: Well, not yet. But I will tomorrow.
Valma: Turn to a policeman nearby right now. I'll have a look at the insurance and see if it's covered.
Tommy: OK, I will.
summary: The cellphone of Tommy's mom was stolen when Tommy was using it.

instruction: Please answer the following question from DialogSum dataset.
question: Why does Sam persuade Maria not to keep non-traditional pets?
dialogue:
Maria: Hi, Sam. I want to buy a pet. Do you have any ideas?
Sam: You really should go to Rachel's pet store.
Maria: why? anything special there?
Sam: it's more than special. You can find as many kinds of animals as you can put a name to and more.
Maria: Oh, really? are there any snakes?
Sam: snakes? there are even rodents and monkeys! it's a world of exotic pets.
Maria: that's terrific. I can't wait to check it out.
Sam: Hang on. are you sure you want to keep a non-traditional pet?
Maria: why not? it's so cool.
Sam: but it will pose a risk to your health.
Maria: pardon?
Sam: i mean, most reptiles carry some harmful bacteria. they are likely to cause immune system problems.
Maria: well, I didn't realize that.
Sam: I don't believe it's a good choice to keep those pets, especially for families with young children.
Maria: oh, I should have thought of my brother's baby girl. Maybe I'll just have a dog instead of an exotic pet.
Sam: yes, good luck, Maria.
summary: Sam persuades Maria not to keep non-traditional pets for health concerns.

instruction: Please answer the following question from DialogSum dataset.
question: What is Lorrin's business protected by?
dialogue:
Burgess: How many years have you done business with China?
Lorrin: Let me see, about five years, we established our business relationship with Hua Mei of China Import & Export Corporation in 2003.
Burgess: Do you have any difficulties in doing business in China? You know the Chinese economic legislation is still incomplete?
Lorrin: I don't think I have any problem with our Chinese partners. They have always followed the contract strictly. We can do business directly with the corporation. As I mentioned before, the Chinese government is trying very hard to perfect its law. Its commercial legislation provides legal protection for foreign companies.
Burgess: Well, it's known that the Sino-American relation is in a dilemma. Does it influence your business in China?
Lorrin: Actually not at present. But we are afraid it will. You know policies influence business to some extent. I hope our government will not be influenced by some extremists. China is really a large market. We don't want to lose it.
Burgess: Thank you.
Lorrin: You're welcome.
summary: Lorrin's business is protected by law and the Sino-American relation hasn't influenced the business from now.

dialogue:
Wakefield: could we possibly discuss my salary some time?

Reagan: of course. It's be against the law if we didn't.
Wakefield: that sounds good to me. I really appreciate it.
Reagan: you are welcome. Come in early tomorrow and I'll show you how to do the scheduling.
summary: a 5% rise

instruction: Please answer the following question from DialogSum dataset.
question: What is Sally's job?
dialogue:
Tom: Hi, Sally.
Sally: Hello, Tom. How are you?
Tom: I'm fine. Where are you going?

Sally: Yeh. I work part-time at a supermarket.
Tom: What do you do there?
Sally: I work in the produce section. Trimming and wrapping fresh fruit and vegetables. I also stock shelves. Sometimes when it really gets busy, work at the check-out counter. Have you got a job, Tom?

Sally: Well, don't work too hard. Holding down a job, going to class, studying. Sometimes it can become too much for one person. Take it easy.
Tom: You, too. It was great seeing you. Sally!
summary: part-time in a supermarket

Hedvig: Argh. . . I feel terrible, I keep sneezing and my eyes are all watery, what's wrong with me?

Herculie: Maybe we should put you into quarantine, ha ha, jokes aside, I think you might have an allergy. 
Hedvig: An allergy? I never thought about that, I don't think I'm allergic to pollen though and I'm desensitized to bee stings after being stung so many times, Hmm. . .

Herculie: Yes, it's Mr. Snuffle's birthday today, I didn't want him to be alone on his special day! 
Hedvig: ACHOO! Argh, put it away, ACHOO!

Ailey: Have you been watching the Euro 2012 football tournament?
Jamie: Just a bit. Have you?

Jamie: Well, I'm from New Jersey. Americans aren't so into football, either. Actually we call it soccer. When Americans say football, what we mean is American rules football. I've been here 2 years now, and I still get confused when people call soccer football.
Ailey: Oh, that's right. For you Americans football means the sport where those big guys wear helmets and violently run into each other.
Jamie: Yeah, Americans prefer watching sports that are fast like basketball. I think basketball players are some of the greatest athletes on earth. What they can do just amazes me. But when I watch a soccer match, I just get board. There aren't enough goals.
Ailey: Well, I see what you're saying. But there's so much more to soccer as you call it than goals. There are a lot of strategies involved. And in a tournament like Euro 2012, it's fascinating to see how the different countries have different styles of playing.
summary: American football and soccer

instruction: Please answer the following question from DialogSum dataset.
question: What caused the fire?
dialogue:
Corby: Hello is that Phil Taylor?
Phil Taylor: Speaking.
Corby: Hi Phil. I'm a Reporter for the Sun. I'm calling to ask you a few questions about the fire. Can you tell me how it happened?
Phil Taylor: Sure. Well it was 2 days ago on November the tenth about 11:00 PM. I decided to fry some chips so I used quite a lot of oil. I was deep frying. Uhm the oil finally got hot enough, so I put the chips in and then my mom rang.
Corby: Ah.
Phil Taylor: We started talking and I completely forgot about the chips. After the call. I just went back to my living room.
Corby: Oh no.
Phil Taylor: Yes, I watch TV for about 20 minutes and the next thing I knew there was the smell of smoke in someone was shouting fire fire. I immediately realized it was my chips. I rushed out of the room. The kitchen was next door. Well, there were flames all over one wall.
Corby: What did you do?
Phil Taylor: Well, I grabbed some blankets from my bed and ran to the kitchen to throw them over the flames. By that time, my neighbors had already called the fire Department. The firefighters arrived, I think within about 10 minutes and put the fire out very quickly.
Corby: So what was the damage.
Phil Taylor: Well. I'll have to replace the cooker completely. Besides, I have to have 2 kitchen units and one wall repaired.
summary: Taylor says that he forgot the chips in the pan

instruction: Please answer the following question from DialogSum dataset.
question: What is Ravil's favorite part of his job?
dialogue:
Gillian: So what made you decide to become a cameraman?
Ravil: Well, I didn't watch TV much, so it wasn't that. I had an uncle Who was a film actor, but I hardly saw him. One day I wandered into a library and picked up the biography of a famous cameraman. I loved it and knew then what I wanted to do.
Gillian: And you've won several prizes for your work?
Ravil: Just one actually. It wasn't like winning a prize for a popular movie or for a special TV advertisement. It was a video for a school program about the development of the cinema.
Gillian: So what about plans for the future? Is Hollywood calling?
Ravil: Well, I'm less interested in working with famous film stars than with students and film academy actually. They got skills that the ordinary person with no training doesn't have but they haven't been affected by success.
Gillian: What do you like best about your job?
Ravil: Well, doing interesting work you see the world but your job is and always in wonderful places and you have lots of chances to get to know some interesting actors and directors. That has to be the best bit from my point of view.
summary: Ravil's favorite part of his job is being a cameraman.

instruction: Please answer the following question from DialogSum dataset.
question: Why does Mr. Brown agree to offer a 5% reduction?
dialogue:
Mr. Brown: Mrs. Wang, would you give us an idea of the price you regard as workable?
Mrs. Wang: As I said before, your price is so high that we find it difficult to make a bid. We hope you will take the initiative and bridge the gap.
Mr. Brown: Just to comply, we're ready to reduce the price by 5 percent. I hope this concession of ours will get the ball rolling.
Mrs. Wang: So do we. Certainly it's a step forward on your side. But the gap is still too wide.
Mr. Brown: The ball is in your court, Mrs.Wang. What price would you suggest?
Mrs. Wang: To make your offer workable, I think you should take another step down as big as the one you've just taken.
Mr. Brown: That won't do. You see, our profit margin is very narrow. It simply can't stand such a big cut.
Mrs. Wang: I hate to disappoint you, Mr. Brown, but if that's the case, we have no alternative but to cover our requirements elsewhere. Do think it over, please. We sincerely hope our discussion will come to a successful conclusion.
Mr. Brown: Well, I'm not authorized to agree to such a big reduction. Would you mind waiting a day or two, until I get a reply from the home office?
Mrs. Wang: Not at all. Shall we meet again, say, on Friday morning?
Mr. Brown: Good. Friday morning at 9.
summary: Mrs. Wang thinks Mr. Brown's price is so high

Lindsay: May I know about the office hours?
Chicky: Office hours are nine to five-thirty. One hour for lunch. Do you have any questions?
Lindsay: Er, may I know how much I will be paid monthly?
Chicky: We'll give you about 3000 to start. There'll be a trial period of three month. After six months, we'll have a job performance review and consider giving you a raise.
Lindsay: When will I know your decision?
Chicky: I'll call you in a day or two, did you write down your phone number on your resume?
Lindsay: Yes, I did. Can you call after 7 p. m. ? I'm usually out in the daytime.
Chicky: All right. Good-bye.
Lindsay: Good-bye.
summary: Chicky'll inform Lindsay of the decision in a day or two by phone.

instruction: Please answer the following question from DialogSum dataset.
question: What game does Lazlo think has a larger space in which to move around?
dialogue:
Lazlo: I like chess better than xiangqi. And you?
xiangqi: For my part, xiangqi. Maybe it's because my girlfriend is Chinese.
Lazlo: I think chess is more reasonable. You see, each side has eight pawns, a larger number than that of the soldiers in xiangqi. A true battle should be like that. Soldiers should outnumber the commanders.
xiangqi: Quite right. And unlike the soldiers in xiangqi, the pawns in chess can promote once they reach the furthest rank. It is very agreeable to grant merits to people with good performance.
Lazlo: Correct! Another contrast is the rules for the general and the king. It seems the general or marshal in xiangqi is much too incompetent. They are required to stay in the palace, waiting to be checked and fleeing for life under the cover of the guards. Look at the king in chess, he is much more capable.
xiangqi: Yeah, and though the king in chess doesn't have bodyguards, he has a queen who is the most powerful piece. I think this demonstrates the relatively higher social status of aristocratic women in medieval Europe than in China.
Lazlo: There's another distinctive contrast. Both board games use a total of 32 pieces, but xiangqi is played on a 9 - by - 9 board, bigger than the 8 - by - 8 board used in chess.
xiangqi: You mean, xiangqi pieces are allowed a larger space in which to move around?
Lazlo: Sure. On a chessboard, fire is much more intensive. It has a smaller board, while those bigger pieces-chariots, horses and bishops-can cover longer distances.
summary: xiangqi

Jane: John, shall we go to Sun Store? I have decided to buy that Murrberry handbag. Anyway,I'm not carrying this one to Mary's wedding.

Jane: Oh, I'd better order one right now.

instruction: Please answer the following question from DialogSum dataset.
question: What does Jennifer Benzes want society to understand?
dialogue:
Loretta: Dear audiences, today we'll talk about divorce and its effect on children. Our guest is Jennifer Benzes. Thank you for coming, Jennifer. Do you mind saying something about your divorce?
Jennifer Benzes: No. I got divorced years ago. Even worse, I got divorced when I had small children.
Loretta: Have you thought of the effect divorce may have on your children? Their needs can be forgotten as parents are struggling to re-establish their lives.
Jennifer Benzes: Of course, we have. We are definitely more aware of the impact on children. After all we are not famous people who trade spouses like shoes. For most of us divorce is not entered into lightly. We all suffer. Anyway, we try to comfort our children.
Loretta: How?
Jennifer Benzes: We tell them we love them and will always do.
Loretta: You haven't thought of saving the marriage?
Jennifer Benzes: Yes, we have. We would do anything to spare our children pain. But you know, fixing a marriage is not like changing a tire. Family conflicts may take hold like a cancer.
Loretta: Then divorce is the only way to get rid of it.
Jennifer Benzes: It's true with me. Others may succeed in fixing.
Loretta: Yet most people believe a hard marriage is better for children than a divorce. According to a recent poll, more people today think parents should stay together for the sake of the children What do you think?
Jennifer Benzes: I think the cost of staying together is worse than the benefits. Parents quarreling and fighting all day may do more harm to their children.
Loretta: What do you want society to do for you?
Jennifer Benzes: Understand us, not curse us. More importantly, they should help us share the loss and build a better future.
summary: fixing a marriage isn't better for children

instruction: Please answer the following question from DialogSum dataset.
question: How does Isadore feel about Beethoven's music?
dialogue:

Isadore: not really. When I was little, we didn't really listen to music at all.
John-David: so, how did you become interested in it?
Isadore: well, when I was about 10 years old, I started playing the piano. I think that's how it all started.
John-David: do you still play piano?
Isadore: yes, it's one of my hobbies.
summary: Isadore thinks it helps people relax

dialogue:
Hyatt: Thanks for coming in today, did you have any trouble finding us? Please take a seat.

I chose this course of study for two reasons. I wanted to gain some practical, marketable skills, which the information management track provided, and I also feel that interpersonal skills are essential for professional success, hence the minor in psychology.
Hyatt: Interesting. And, your postgraduate studies?

Hyatt: Interesting. . .
Danika: Yes, in this position I was able to make some pretty significant contributions to the overall success of the company. With the different initiatives that we implemented, we lowered our churn rate to about five percent, which had a direct impact on revenue.
summary: undergraduate and postgraduate studies

instruction: Please answer the following question from DialogSum dataset.
question: How does Alyss feel about exercise?
dialogue:
Kristien: I don't understand why you always look so happy, so energetic. It seems like you'Ve got good news everyday.
Alyss: Really? Do I look happy all the time?
Kristien: All I know is you look quite differently from other teachers.
Alyss: Oh, do you know why? Actually, it's easy. Because I always exercise. My exercise, I think, is very hard. I often feel very good after conquering these difficulties. I feel alive!
Kristien: Oh, I know. I saw you doing pull-ups one time on the campus 5 and some students trying to imitate you.
Alyss: Yeah, they are doing it for fun. Seldom would people like my exercise. It's difficult and boring.
Kristien: It's true. Many students do the exercise when they have to. We have P. E. once a week.
Alyss: But I think Chinese students need to exercise more. Besides exercise will help them learn new things better. Don't students want to have a good memory?
Kristien: Of course. I didn't know that. I only know exercise makes bodies stronger. I should take some exercise then. Do you have any suggestions?
Alyss: Well, do what you like to do. It can be anything. Jogging, doing aerobics, going bicycling, and playing ping-pong. Absolutely anything. Doing three or more workouts a week is good for you. But remember to do some stretches first.
Kristien: Oh, I know. Thank you.
summary: Alyss shares with Kristien that doing exercise helps people keep a good memory and make people stronger.

instruction: Please answer the following question from DialogSum dataset.
question: What is the name of the dog that Brooks wants to take home?
dialogue:
Brooks: Hey. Can you give me a hand with the groceries? And I told you I could do the shopping.
Nickolas: Wow! Do we really need all this stuff? Let me see that receipt.
Brooks: Hey, I only bought the essentials.
Nickolas: Okay. Let's see. Dog food. Twenty-four dollars and seventy cents ($24.70)? We don't even have a dog!
Brooks: Well, it WAS going to be a surprise, but look in the back of the truck.
Nickolas: What?
Brooks: Ah, ha, hah. Speechless. I knew you'd love him.
Nickolas: That thing? That dog's as big as a horse. He probably eats like one, too.
Brooks: Ah, but he's sure friendly. And someone was giving him away at the supermarket, and I... I... I couldn't let that poor thing pass another day without a loving home.
Nickolas: Whatever. Where was I? Eighteen dollars and nineteen cents ($18.19) for twenty-four cans of tomato juice? You don't even like that stuff!
Brooks: Ahhhh. Not yet. I've decided to change my eating habits.
Nickolas: Right.
Brooks: You'll see, you'll see.
Nickolas: Okay. Let's see. Three eighty-four ($3.84) for a box of chocolate cookies and twelve fifty-six ($12.56) for a case of soft drinks.
Brooks: Yeah!
Nickolas: Changing your eating habits, huh? Do you really think that cookies are some type of diet food?
Brooks: Hey, I'll just eat a cookie or two every other hour. In fact, they're a great source of carbohydrates for energy. And, you see, the tomato juice and cookies kind of, you know, cancel each other out.
Nickolas: Oh brother. I can't believe what I'm hearing. Let's see. Where was I? A carton of eggs, two fifty ($2.50) for a gallon of milk, three cans of tuna. Okay. [Yeah.] And finally two steaks for eight fourteen ($8.14). Now, something worth enjoying. I'll get the grill started.
Brooks: Oh, we... w... well. The steaks are for Herbert.
Nickolas: Herbert. Who's Herbert?
Brooks: Uh, he's the dog.
Nickolas: No!
Brooks: You see, the previous owner said that he's kind of... he's somewhat picky about what he eats.
Nickolas: No!
Brooks: And the steaks might help him adjust.
Nickolas: Absolutely not!
Brooks: No, no, no, and the steaks might help him adjust to his new home. Hey, what are you doing? Oh, no. Why did you throw the steaks out on the ground outside?
Nickolas: Well, now, you and Herbert can get to know each other better. I'm going out to eat by myself.
Brooks: Ughh.
summary: Herbet, but Nickolas is angrier when he finds the steaks are for Herbert

question: What does Mady share with Jilleen?
dialogue:
Jilleen: Thank you. The tea smells good. What is it called?
Mady: It's called Tie Guanyin, and is a kind of Wulong tea.
Jilleen: I've heard this name before, but I could never understand the tea classification.
Mady: It's confusing and there is no agreement on it. Generally speaking, there are 4 kinds of tea based on processing methods. They're green tea, black tea, Wulong tea and scented tea.
Jilleen: It is said that different kinds of tea have different health benefits, isn't it?
Mady: Yes, it is. But there are also considerations of time and personal health. For example, green tea is good in summer. It seems to drive away the heat and bring a feeling of relaxation. However, pregnant women should not drink it.
Jilleen: There seems to be a lot to know about tea. You must tell me more about tea culture in the future.
Mady: Sure, I'll be glad to.
summary: knowledge of different teas

instruction: Please answer the following question from DialogSum dataset.
question: What does Phaidra tell Elli should be prepared for keeping fish?
dialogue:
Elli: I saw a beautiful fish in the market the other day, it was orange and blue. I'm thinking of buying some next Sunday.
Phaidra: Where would you keep them?
Elli: In that round bottle over there.
Phaidra: It's a bit small, isn't it?
Elli: So are the fish.
Phaidra: I think you should get a tank if you want to keep fish.
Elli: Really?
Phaidra: Yes, you should never keep fish in a small round bottle. They don't get enough air. I suggest we go shopping together and look for a nice tank.
Elli: That might be quite expensive.
Phaidra: Check the prices before you buy one and you ought to put a few large rocks in the tank. Fish love swimming around the rocks and through holes in them.
Elli: Is there anything else that I ought to get?
Phaidra: Yes, you need to get some underwater plants, for one thing they keep the water clean, also they make the tank look much prettier.
summary: a tank, some rocks, and underwater plants

question: Who saw Jared buying the ring?
dialogue:
Jared: Trina, will you marry me?
Trina: Yes! Yes! And yes! Jared, of course I'll marry you!
Jared: Oh, Babe, I can't wait to spend the rest of my life with you! I can't wait for all the adventures we're going to have, for all the fights and the laughter. I can't wait to grow old and wrinkly with you.
Trina: Oh, Jared! I can't wait for our wedding! I hope you don't mind, but I'Ve already chosen a date! Six months from now in the summer! Melissa saw you buying the ring last month so I'Ve had plenty of time to start planning!
Jared: She what?
Trina: Oh don't worry, sweetie, I didn't know when you were going to propose. It was still a nice surprise! As I was saying, I'Ve got it all planned out. There's almost nothing left to do! I wrote up our guest list and we will have roughly four hundred guests attending.
Jared: Four hundred?
Trina: No need to sweat it. My parents agreed to pay for most of the wedding, which is going to be low-budget anyway. So roughly four hundred people, which means that the hall at Northwoods Heights will be our reception venue. I thought it would be nice if we had the wedding at your parents'church and my uncle of course would be officiating. We'll meet with him soon for some pre-wedding counseling. The music for the wedding ceremony was a no-brainer. My step-sister and her string quartet will take care of that. My cousin will be the official photographer. I thought it would also be nice if his daughter could sing a solo. Did you know that she's going to be a professional opera singer?
Jared: Ah. . .
Trina: And then of course the ladies at the church would love to be our caterers for the banquet and we'll get the Youth Group to serve us. I was thinking that your friend's band could be our entertainment for the night. though they might have to tone it down a bit. Or we could hire a DJ. Your sister's husband could get us a discount with that company that does the decor at weddings. what's their name again? I was thinking that we could have an island paradise-themed wedding and our theme color would be a soothing blue like Aquamarine. And there will be a huge seashell on the wall behind the podium where we'll make our toasts! What do you think of small packages of drink mixes for our wedding favors? Who else am I missing? Oh, your uncle could be our florist and his wife could make our wedding cake!
Jared: Wow.
Trina: See? It's going to be wonderful! Oh this wedding is going to be everything I ever dreamed of.
Jared: If I survive the next six months.
summary: Trina already knew from Melissa who saw him buying the ring that he was planning this.

instruction: Please answer the following question from DialogSum dataset.
question: Why is Ethan not cheerful?
dialogue:
Ava: Are you alright, Ethan? You don't seem to be as cheerful as you normally are.
Ethan: To be honest, Ava, I've just had a really bad day.
Ava: What happened?
Ethan: First, I slept through my alarm and ended up two hours late to work.
Ava: What did your boss say?
Ethan: He told me that if I showed up late one more time, he'd fire me. He's so mean!
Ava: That's horrible. Was that the first time you'd shown up late to work?
Ethan: That was my second time. The first time, I was in a car accident.
Ava: Is your boss Chinese?
Ethan: No, he's from Australia. Before I met him, I thought Australians were supposed to be relaxed and easy-going. I had no idea he'd be so fussy about things.
Ava: What are you going to do?
Ethan: I think I'm going to look for another job. I need to find a boss that is a bit more sensitive and optimistic than my current boss.
Ava: That sounds like a sensible plan. Do you want me to help you with your job search?
Ethan: That's very generous of you. Thanks for the offer.
Ava: Don't mention it. That's what friends are for!
summary: his boss threats to fire him if he shows up late one more time

instruction: Please answer the following question from DialogSum dataset.
question: Why did Monica have to give up her shopping plan with Lucy?
dialogue:
Jody: So, Monica, what do you feel like doing this afternoon?
Monica: Actually, I had a perfect plan for this afternoon, but it is totally ruined by the sand storm. I woke up this morning and found it was sunny. So I called Lucy and asked her to go shopping with me. We were going to look for a new purse. Now it turned out to be like this. Neither of us wants to go to outside anymore.
Jody: That's too bad. I hate sand storms too. It can be worse than any kind of bad weather.
Monica: What's wrong with climate? Anyway, I think the sand storm happens more frequently these days than the years before. Can't people do something to stop it?
Jody: It is not an easy job. The government is working on it. Lots of trees have been planted in the north of the capital. Also, methods of generating rain are being used by the government to fight against the drought. But of course, it will not work overnight. So, have you come out with a new plan for today?
Monica: My new plan is to wait for the end of the sand storm and clean my apartment.
summary: Monica had to give up her shopping plan with Lucy because of the sand storm.

instruction: Please answer the following question from DialogSum dataset.
question: What does Mrs. Brown suggest Guthrie do?
dialogue:
Mrs. Brown: Good morning. What seems to be the problem?
Guthrie: Good morning, Mrs. Brown. I have a cough and a fever and I feel very tired all the time.
Mrs. Brown: And how long have you been feeling like this?
Guthrie: Three days now.
Mrs. Brown: Let me have a look. Open your mouth please. Wider please. Now say AHH.
Guthrie: AHHH.
Mrs. Brown: Now take your shirt off please. Breathe in-Breathe out-OK, you can put your shirt back on now.
Guthrie: What seems to be the problem? Do I suffer from bird flu or is there something wrong with my lung?
Mrs. Brown: Oh, no. Don't be so nervous. You just have a bad cold. Do you work in an air-conditioned office?
Guthrie: Yes, I do.
Mrs. Brown: I thought so. I see many people who work in air-conditioned offices. It's the air conditioning, you see. It's really not very good for your health.
Guthrie: So what would you suggest, doctor?
Mrs. Brown: I suggest you get out of the office as regularly as possible. Walk around, and get some fresh air. That will help. You also need to get more exercise. Do you play any sports?
Guthrie: I sometimes play tennis in summer, but to be honest, I'm too busy to get regular exercise.
Mrs. Brown: Then I suggest you try playing more often. Say once a week.
Guthrie: OK, no problem. Thank you doctor. Bye.
Mrs. Brown: Bye.
summary: get out of the air-conditioned offices as regularly as possible and do more exercise

Breanne: With the cost of gasoline these days, that is a big plus. I think this model may be just what I'm looking for. 
Adrick: Why don't you take it for a test drive, and think it over.
summary: a test drive and think it over

Shelden: Oh, terrible.

They all have it as a goal that they're going to get out of the program. Jerry: Today's a work day. So when I go back into the shop, I have all my students working on a project. First, Jack is going to get the air tools out and jack up a car. He's going to take a tyre off that car with the air impact. Every student is an individual that comes into my program. All of them think that they're going to be able to fix their own cars. They all have it as a goal that they're going to get out of the program. And then, as part of my introduction to the class, I'll let them know some of the other things that they'll all get, which include consumer understanding of how the car works.

instruction: Please answer the following question from DialogSum dataset.
question: How many times has the prescription been refilled?
dialogue:
Hatti: Excuse me. I need to refill this prescription.
Sheri: It says on the bottle here that you can have two refills.
Hatti: Yes, I need to refill it today.
Sheri: Alright. I'm sorry, Miss. According to our file, this prescription has already been refilled twice.
Hatti: I was worried about that. I couldn't remember if I had it refilled twice yet or not.
Sheri: Well, it looks like you have.You will need to see your doctor to get a new prescription.
Hatti: Listen. This is an emergency. I tried to call my doctor, but he is out of town. So I can't see him in time. I need this medicine. It is for skin condition. I've run out.Can you just refill it once more?
Sheri: I'm sorry, Miss. We can't do it. We must follow the prescription.And this prescription has run out.
Hatti: But I need it. Please. Refill it for me just this once. I can go to the doctor around ten days from now. Then I'll have another prescription.
Sheri: Miss, I understand your problem.But it is against the law for us to sell certain medicines without a prescription.It ' s the law. I can't do anything about it.We never sell medicine unless we have a proper prescription. Never.
Hatti: But I have a prescription. I just need more of it.
Sheri: A prescription must be valid. It cannot be an expired prescription. I'm sorry, Miss. It's the law.You will have to find another doctor who will prescribe this for you.
Hatti: Oh, it will be so expensive! I have a special medical plan, and I can only see one doctor.It will cost me a lot of money to see another doctor.
Sheri: Miss, I just can't help you on this. I'm a pharmacist, not a doctor. And there are other customers I need to help now. I know it is frustrating when this happens.But there is nothing I can do about it. I'm sorry.
Hatti: This is ridiculous! In Taiwan, it is much easier to get medicine when I need it.
Sheri: Maybe that's true. I don't know.But I'm sure in Taiwan you have prescriptions too.
summary: twice, but Sheri refuses her because it has been refilled twice. Hatti insists as it's an emergency.

instruction: Please answer the following question from DialogSum dataset.
question: What does Stacy think of show biz stars?
dialogue:
Stacy: I think that show biz stars have a really easy life. They have lots of money, so they can buy almost anything they want. They're famous, so everyone loves them.
Bryna: I think they must have horrible lives. All the paparazzi take photos of them wherever they go and whatever they do. They must get sick of it.
Stacy: I bet they love it really. Sure, they complain about it, but that just gets them more publicity, doesn't it?
Bryna: I think that few of the show biz stars want any publicity for themselves. They only want it for their films.
Stacy: No way! They want publicity for themselves, so that they get invited to make more films, go to lots of cocktail parties, and even make albums! They have such an easy life. They don't even pay for drinks when they go to a cocktail party.
Bryna: Show biz stars have plenty of expenses. That's why they need so much money. They need million of dollars to buy big, seclude houses and wonderful dresses. I bet most show biz stars would prefer to wear jeans and a t-shirt, but they can't because their managers force them to wear clothes they don't like.
Stacy: I don't understand how you can have any sympathy for show biz stars. They're overpaid, over-ambitious, and over-adored.
Bryna: I think you should give them some credit. They're very talented people and they deserve all the money they earn. They even donate money to charity to help people who are less fortunate than themselves.
Stacy: Come on! They only do that to get even more publicity for their films and themselves.
summary: they have an easy life, they love publicity to get them more films and social activities

instruction: Please answer the following question from DialogSum dataset.
question: What do Ruddie and Melissa agree to do on Friday night?
dialogue:
Ruddie: What do you want to do tomorrow night?
Melissa: What--is tomorrow night something special?
Ruddie: It's Friday. We should go party.
Melissa: I don't need to drink every weekend. I could be happy just staying home, you know.
Ruddie: Okay. Stay home Sunday. But Friday we should go out dancing.
Melissa: Do you feel like dancing?
Ruddie: Yes? Why not?
Melissa: Alright. At least that's better than sitting in a bar with your alcoholic friends.
Ruddie: They aren't alcoholic!
Melissa: No, maybe they're not. But they're close.
Ruddie: So where should we go?
Melissa: Let's go to the Latin Club. I think they will have a Brazilian band there this weekend. Maybe it's Friday night.
Ruddie: You always want to go to the Latin Club. I don't know those dance steps. I'd rather go to the New Bar.
Melissa: The New Bar is all techno music on Friday night. You really want to dance to that?
Ruddie: It's not all techno music. It's not a special techno night.
Melissa: No. But they play techno all the time. It drives me crazy after forty minutes. And anyhow, if we go to the Latin Club you could actually learn some Latin dance steps. At the New Bar you'll just shake yourself around for an hour. And then you'll get sick of stand you'll want to go get drunk somewhere where the drinks are cheaper. I know you.
Ruddie: It's fine with me if we go to the Latin Club. I like Latin Music. The only thing I never want to do again is listen to country rock. What was that bar called?
Melissa: Oh. You mean Jerry's, over on the east side. That wasn't my idea going there.
Ruddie: No. It was that friend of yours, Melissa. Her and all her lousy country music Cds. Yecch!
Melissa: It's true. I would never go there again either. Country music is a nightmare. So is it the Latin Club?
Ruddie: Yes. You have to teach me the samba, and the tango, and whatever else they do.
Melissa: Well, it seems you'll have to learn some Spanish too, won't you?
Ruddie: Maybe.
summary: go to the Latin Club

instruction: Please answer the following question from DialogSum dataset.
question: What does Raymundo tell Sophronia is similar to the yard sale in China?
dialogue:
Sophronia: I have found it quite different here from China since I came to the United States.
Raymundo: What's the difference?
Sophronia: Some friends of mine took me to the mall to go shopping. It was so big. I think I could get lost if I went there alone.
Raymundo: You must have bought many things in the mall?
Sophronia: Not really many. I was told that on weekends there were always the flea markets, so I decided to come to the flea market to buy a bargain.
Raymundo: It's wise to do it. The Americans have the habit of selling their junk when they are moving to another place, so they usually display all the things they want to sell in their gardens at the weekend. And many things they are selling still look quite new and they are also very useful.
Sophronia: I have heard about it while in China. it is called a ' yard sale '. I didn't have any idea of that until today when I came here to the big ' yard sale '.
Raymundo: You must have got many useful things for your new apartment.
summary: Americans have a habit of selling still new and useful things when moving

instruction: Please answer the following question from DialogSum dataset.
question: What does Kurtis advise Darryl to do?
dialogue:
Kurtis: Hi dude, you look upset, what's up?
Darryl: Haven't been sleeping well recently.
Kurtis: What's the problem?
Darryl: Every night my roommates watch the Korean soap operas till mid-night. I am not a big fan of Korean shows and I don't know how to tell them to stop without hurting their feelings.
Kurtis: Well, you can simply tell them you want to sleep, or make an agreement for a time when the room should quiet down.
Darryl: Yeah, I know, but I find these sorts of things hard to say. They won't like it if I tell them to turn off the TV. Now I just hope the show will end soon.
Kurtis: I understand. I used to live in a dorm with four people. I was great in some aspects. We always went out and and had fun together. But on the other hand, when I wanted some quiet time, and people kept talking and laughing aloud, it was torturous. For me a room to myself, even a small one, is ideal. Though I don't mind sharing an apartment with somebody.
Darryl: Yeah, I crave my own space. I just get so tiredhaving people around me all the time. We all need our private space. But I also think interpersonal skills very important. Living in a dorm means you have to learn to be considerate of others, otherwise nobody is going to have a good time.
summary: tell them about it or make an agreement for keeping quiet

instruction: Please answer the following question from DialogSum dataset.
question: What does Johnny think will happen to the city square?
dialogue:
Johnny: Hi, Wendy.
Wendy: Oh, Johnny. How are you doing, busy?
Johnny: No, not at all. I've been a couch potato lately, killing time by watching TV. Oh, by the way, did you hear the news?
Wendy: No. What is it?
Johnny: They are going to turn the city square into an amusement park.
Wendy: Wonderful! I'm glad that big ugly things will be gone.
Johnny: You really are? In my opinion, the square is 100 times better than an amusement park.
Wendy: I don't see why.
Johnny: The square is a symbol of our city and it is a nice place to have a walk for everybody.
Wendy: Well, I don't know if that huge and boring thing can be our symbol, but I know for sure the city has tens of parks where you can take a nice walk.
Johnny: I know what you mean, but don't you think that we will no longer have peace and quiet once the amusement park opens?
Wendy: Does that matter? To me, more importantly, the amusement park means employment.
Johnny: So what?
Wendy: Income. If you have income, you have money to spend, and in turn, it'll create more jobs.
summary: Johnny thinks they will lose their city's symbol and a quiet place

question: Why did Mary argue with Ann?
dialogue:
Mary: Hi Mary, how's it going? 
Malorie: Well, last night I had a big argument with Ann. 
Mary: Terrible. It must be something serious. You two are such close friends. 
Malorie: Now that I look back at it, it wasn't that big a deal. I shouldn't have lost my temper. 
Mary: Really? What happened? 
Malorie: It's just we've been planning to go the beach for a while, and we decided we could both make it this weekend. Then out of nowhere she called me up, said her boyfriend had made plans and that she need to cancel the trip. I was so angry when she told me that I said she didn't care about our friendship at all. 
Mary: That's pretty harsh. 
Malorie: I know, but I was so upset. I mean, come on! Does she have to do everything her boyfriend says? 
Mary: You know she probably feels just as bad. 
Malorie: Well, I think I was being a little selfish myself. I know they don't get to see each other very often. 
Mary: Well, in that case I guess maybe you can be more understanding. You shouldn't let a trivial thing like this stand in the way of your friendship. After all you can go to the beach anytime you want. 
Malorie: Yeah, I'll call later to patch things up.
summary: Ann needed to cancel their trip and went to her boyfriend's plan

question: How does Maribeth feel about Eberhard?
dialogue:
Maribeth: Are the galaxies in the universe moving through space?
Eberhard: No, the galaxies sit more or less passively in the space around them. But not too much. As the space between galaxies expands, it carries the galaxies further apart - like raisins in an expanding dough.
Maribeth: But I heard that our Milky way galaxy may one day collide with a neighboring galaxy. If galaxies are moving apart from each other, how can they collide?
Eberhard: Well, the universe is a chaotic place, and the gravity from one galaxy, or from a group of galaxies, may disturb the motion of its near neighbors, causing them to collide. However, on average, when you compare two large enough chunks of space, the galaxies in one are moving away from the galaxies in the other.
Maribeth: Wow, you're really informative. Thanks a lot.
Eberhard: You're welcome.
summary: Maribeth thinks Eberhard is informative.

Lila: You are married to a foreigner, huh? So what's it like?

Marie-Jeanne: Right now he speaks mostly Chinese, and he can say a few English words. But he will learn.
Lila: What does he look like? Can people tell?
Marie-Jeanne: Yes, people surely can. He's whiter than the Chinese kids, and his hair is a little blonde. My husband says his eyes are very Chinese though.
summary: marriage with a foreigner

instruction: Please answer the following question from DialogSum dataset.
question: What is the name of the hotel?
dialogue:
Vivienne: Did you enjoy your weekend at the highland hotel? I heard it's and excellent place to stay and has good facilities.
Becky: I had a wonderful time. The rooms are not very big, but they are well furnished. The restaurant is excellent and reasonably priced. There's a sauna and a Jacuzzi.
Vivienne: Do they have a swimming pool?
Becky: No, they don't. they have a beauty parlor, but I didn't go there.
Vivienne: What's the service like?
Becky: It's very good. Check in and check out at the reception only took a few minutes. The wait staff is very good. A waiter recommended their baked fish, which tasted wonderful. The hotel was quite full, so I'd suggest making a reservation if you intend to go there. The hotel offers a discount at the weekends.
Vivienne: It sounds perfect. Did you have any complaints at all?
Becky: There was a problem with the internet access, so I couldn't check my email, but I didn't complain about it to the management.
Vivienne: I suppose you were happy to forget about the outside world.
Becky: Yes, I was. Here's their business card.
Vivienne: Thanks. Was there a mina bar in the room?
Becky: No, there wasn't. There is a bar on the ground floor and of course you can buy drinks in the restaurant to go with your meal.
Vivienne: One of the things I dislike about hotels is that everyone expects tips.
Becky: I know. At the inland hotel, they have an interesting policy. When you check out, you put some money in a special box at reception. Each evening, the money in the box is shared equally by the hotel staff.
summary: the highland hotel

Laurel: Good afternoon, madam. How can I help you?
Correna: Well, I am a little bit out of shape. I think I should get some exercise to keep fit. what kind of service do you offer?
Laurel: First of all, we'll tailor a work-out plan according to your physical conditions and your personal needs.
Correna: How can you get that done?
Laurel: Well, we give each of our customers a qualified personal trainer. The trainer will give you a fitness assessment and then come up with the work-out plan.
Correna: What else?
Laurel: Since everyone is different, your personal trainer will help you find out all the exercise equipments that are suitable for you fitness level. Then you'll be taught all the necessary techniques to use these equipments and achieve your goal.
Correna: Sounds pretty good. How much do you charge?
Laurel: That depends. We offer membership for one month, half a year and one year.
Correna: Perhaps one month. I'll just have a try at first.
Laurel: Wise decision. that is 400 yuan. You'll find it's totally worth it.
Correna: OK, I'll take it.

instruction: Please answer the following question from DialogSum dataset.
question: What industry has neither job loss nor picking up?
dialogue:
Colbert: Welcome. Last month big leap in new job, some 300, 000 plus, is a huge increase over what the country has seen in the past 6 months when the average growth has been just 75, 000 new jobs a month. For a closer look at what's happening, we turn to Lisa Lynch, an economics professor at Tofts University. Lisa Lynch, when you look at these numbers, do you think job creation is on the rise?
Lisa Lynch: It certainly is. It was a great report. It indicates that the job market, broadly speaking, has turned the corner after 3 very long, lean years. I think we are going to see improvement. It's not only the March gain. It was gain in January and February. They were both revised higher, and moreover, the job gains were very broadly-based across many industries. It was a very positive report.
Colbert: What do you see in the numbers? Who's getting the new jobs?
Lisa Lynch: As I mentioned, when we looked at the numbers, 'we are seeing employment across the board in all sectors, with one important exception, and that's in manufacturing. Well, we do not have any job loss in manufacturing sector for the first time in 44 months. We did not see pick up in the manufacturing sector, but we saw restaurant and hotel workers being added on. We saw workers in supermarket being added on. Part of that reflects the settlement of the grocery stores strike out California. We saw workers in the health care sector and hospitals being added on. We saw business services adding employees. So in general, with the very important exception of manufacturing, we are seeing job growth across all of these different types of occupations.
summary: manufacturing which has neither job loss nor picking up.

instruction: Please answer the following question from DialogSum dataset.
question: What does Bill Gate's home have?
dialogue:
Janean: Have you ever seen Bill Gate's home on the internet? 
Fanechka: No. what's it like? 
Janean: It's got its own library, theatre, swimming pool, and a guest house. The house itself has about ten different rooms that are all hooked up to computers so you can get things done in each room through a remote control. It's also located near the sea, so he can park his boats next to his house. It's absolutely amazing! 
Fanechka: Would you want to live there? 
Janean: I think his house is fantastic, but I wouldn't want to live there. You would have to hire one or two people to clean all the rooms in the house, plus a few people to take care of the gardens, and probably an au pair or two to take care of the children. It's just too big of a place to take care of on your own. 
Fanechka: What's your dreamhome like then? 
Janean: My dream home is actually just a small cottage in a quiet village in England.
Fanechka: Would you want to buy an old cottage or build a new one yourself? 
Janean: Old homes are great because they've got character. I think that's important. 
Fanechka: Is that why you wear second-hand clothes as well? Because they've got character? 
Janean: No, that's just because I don't have enough money to buy new cloths all the time! 
Fanechka: I see. If you lived in an old house, would it be decorated in a modern way? 
Janean: No, I'd definitely try to restore it to its original state. I love to imagine what it'd be like to live in another time in history and living in a house decorated like it would have been 200 years ago would be a great way to feed my imagination even more!
summary: library, theatre, swimming pool, and a guest house

summary: her boss's sexist comments

instruction: Please answer the following question from DialogSum dataset.
question: What does Morrie think of Ronnie's job?
dialogue:
Morrie: I can't believe it's almost summer.
Ronnie: Yeah, I know. The year went really fast.
Morrie: What are you going to do this summer vacation?
Ronnie: I'm going to work for a company.
Morrie: A company? What's that? What do you do?
Ronnie: We help at parties. Our company prepares and serves the food, and usually another company provides the music.
Morrie: I didn't know you could cook.
Ronnie: I don't have to cook. I'm only an assistant.
Morrie: When do you start?
Ronnie: Tomorrow. We're helping a birthday party. Then a big family get together.
Morrie: So, what exactly do you do?
Ronnie: Before the party starts, I help set everything up. You know, bring the food in and arrange the tables, make sure it looks nice.
Morrie: Sounds pretty easy.
Ronnie: That's only the first part. During the party, I have to serve food and drinks to the guests.
Morrie: Well, at least you get to meet people.
Ronnie: Yeah, and after the party is finished, I help clean up.
Morrie: Yuck, I hate to wash dishes.
Ronnie: Oh, I don't wash dishes. Someone else does. I just put everything in the truck.
Morrie: That's not so bad. Sounds like a cool job.
summary: Morrie thinks that's a cool job.
